briefdescription.para: a triple of periodic points representing a triangle in the periodic domain.

description.para: The vertices and faces of the triangulations are accessed through handles, iterators and circulators.

The handles areIs Model Of
of the concept Handle which basically offers the two dereference operators and ->. The iterators and circulators are all bidirectional and non-mutable. The circulators and iterators are convertible to handles with the same value type, so that whenever a handle appear in the parameter list of a function, an appropriate iterator or circulator can be passed as well.
The edges of the triangulation can also be visited through iterators and circulators, the edge circulators and iterators are also bidirectional and non-mutable.

briefdescription.para: handle to a vertex.
handle to a face.
iterator over all faces.
iterator over all edges.
iterator over all vertices.
iterator over the vertices whose corresponding points lie in the original domain, i.e.

detaileddescription.para: for each set of periodic copies the Unique_vertex_iterator iterates over exactly one representative.

briefdescription.para: circulator over all faces incident to a given vertex.
circulator over all edges incident to a given vertex.
circulator over all vertices adjacent to a given vertex.
iterator over the triangles corresponding to faces of the triangulation.
iterator over the segments corresponding to edges of the triangulation.
iterator over the points corresponding to vertices of the triangulation.
Introduces an empty triangulation t with domain as original domain.
Copy constructor.

detaileddescription.para: All the vertices and faces are duplicated. After the copy, this and tr refer to different triangulations: if tr is modified, this is not.

briefdescription.para: Assignment.

detaileddescription.para: All the vertices and faces are duplicated. After the assignment, this and tr refer to different triangulations: if tr is modified, this is not.

briefdescription.para: The triangulations tr and this are swapped.

detaileddescription.para: t.swap(tr) should be preferred to this = tr or to t(tr) if tr is deleted after that.

briefdescription.para: Deletes all faces and vertices resulting in an empty triangulation.

description.para: The responsibility of keeping a valid triangulation belongs to the user when using advanced operations allowing a direct manipulation of the tds.

briefdescription.para: Returns a const reference to the triangulation traits object.
Returns a const reference to the triangulation data structure.
Returns the original domain.
Returns the number of sheets of the covering space the triangulation is currently computed in.
Returns the dimension of the convex hull.

detaileddescription.para: The dimension is zero if the triangulation is empty and two otherwise.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of vertices.

detaileddescription.para: Counts all vertices that are representatives of the same point in $ \mathbb T_c^2$ as one vertex.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of faces.

detaileddescription.para: Counts all faces that are representatives of the same triangle in $ \mathbb T_c^2$ as one face.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of vertices in the data structure.

detaileddescription.para: This is the same as the number of sheets times number_of_vertices().

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of faces in the data structure.

detaileddescription.para: This is the same as the number of sheets times number_of_faces().

description.para: This method is mainly a help for users implementing their own triangulation algorithms.

briefdescription.para: Returns a reference to the triangulation data structure.
Returns the number of edges.

detaileddescription.para: Counts all edges that are representatives of the same segment in $ \mathbb T_c^2$ as one edge.

briefdescription.para: Returns the number of edges in the data structure.

detaileddescription.para: This is the same as the number of sheets times number_of_edges().

description.para: It is not recommended to interfere with the built-in covering management.
Especially a premature conversion to the 1-sheeted covering space might lead to problems when modifying the triangulation later.

briefdescription.para: The current triangulation remains a triangulation in the 1-sheeted covering space even after adding points if this method returns true.

detaileddescription.para: This test relies on a heuristic, i.e. if it answers false nothing is known. This test runs in constant-time when not computing in the 1-sheeted covering space. (This test uses the length of the longest edge in the triangulation as a criterion [1].)

briefdescription.para: The same as is_extensible_triangulation_in_1_sheet_h1() but with a more precise heuristic, i.e.

detaileddescription.para: it might answer true in cases in which is_extensible_triangulation_in_1_sheet_h1() would not. However, it is much less time efficient when not computing in the 1-sheeted covering space. (This test uses the diameter of the largest empty circle in the input point set as a criterion [1].)

briefdescription.para: Returns true if the current triangulation would still be a triangulation in the 1-sheeted covering space, returns false otherwise.
Converts the current triangulation into the same periodic triangulation in the 1-sheeted covering space.
Converts the current triangulation into the same periodic triangulation in the 9-sheeted covering space.
Returns the periodic point given by vertex v.

detaileddescription.para: If this is represented in the 1-sheeted covering space, the offset is always zero. Otherwise v can correspond to a periodic copy outside the domain of an input point.

briefdescription.para: If this is represented in the 1-sheeted covering space, this function returns the periodic point given by the $ i$-th vertex of face f, that is the point in the original domain and the offset of the vertex in f.

detaileddescription.para:
If this is represented in the 9-sheeted covering space, this offset is possibly added to another offset determining the periodic copy.
$ i \in\{0,1,2\}$

briefdescription.para: Returns the periodic segment formed by the two point-offset pairs corresponding to the two vertices of edge (f,i).
Same as the previous method for edge e.
Returns the periodic triangle formed by the three point-offset pairs corresponding to the three vertices of facet f.

description.para: Note that a traits class providing exact constructions should be used in order to guarantee the following operations to be exact (as opposed to computing the triangulation only, which requires only exact predicates).

briefdescription.para: Converts the Periodic_point pp (point-offset pair) to the corresponding Point in $ \mathbb R^3$.
Converts the Periodic_segment s to a Segment.
Converts the Periodic_triangle this to a Triangle.
Equivalent to the call t.segment(t.periodic_segment(f,i));
Equivalent to the call t.segment(t.periodic_segment(e));
Equivalent to the call t.segment(t.periodic_segment(ec->first, ec->second));
Equivalent to the call t.segment(t.periodic_segment(ei->first, ei->second));
Equivalent to the call t.triangle(t.periodic_triangle(f));

description.para: The class Periodic_2_triangulation_2 provides methods to test the presence in the triangulation of a particular feature (edge or face).

briefdescription.para: true if there is an edge having va and vb as vertices.
as above.

detaileddescription.para: In addition, if true is returned, the edge with vertices va and vb is the edge e=(fr,i) where fr is a handle to the face incident to e and on the right side of e oriented from va to vb.

briefdescription.para: true if there is a face having v1, v2 and v3 as vertices.

memberdef.argsstring: (Vertex_handle v1, Vertex_handle v2, Vertex_handle v3, Face_handle &fr)
memberdef.name: is_face

briefdescription.para: as above.

detaileddescription.para: In addition, if true is returned, fr is a handle to the face with v1, v2 and v3 as vertices.

description.para: The class Periodic_2_triangulation_2 provides methods to locate a given point with respect to a triangulation.
It also provides methods to locate a point with respect to a given face of the triangulation.

briefdescription.para: If the triangulation is not empty, a face that contains the query in its interior or on its boundary is returned.

detaileddescription.para: If the triangulation is empty, the default constructed Face_handle is returned.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &query, Locate_type &lt, int &li, Face_handle h=Face_handle()) const
memberdef.name: locate

briefdescription.para: Same as above.

detaileddescription.para: Additionally, the parameters lt and li describe where the query point is located. The variable lt is set to the locate type of the query. If lt==VERTEX the variable li is set to the index of the vertex, and if lt==EDGE li is set to the index of the vertex opposite to the edge. Be careful that li has no meaning when the query type is FACE or when the triangulation is $ 0$-dimensional.

briefdescription.para: Returns on which side of the oriented boundary of f the point p lies.

description.para: The following iterators allow the user to visit faces, edges and vertices of the stored triangulation, i.e.

in case of computing in a multiply sheeted covering space all stored periodic copies of each item are returned. These iterators are non-mutable, bidirectional and their value types are respectively Face, Edge and Vertex. They are all invalidated by any change in the triangulation.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary vertex.
Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary edge.
Past-the-end iterator.
Starts at an arbitrary face.
Past-the-end iterator.

description.para: The following iterators allow the user to obtain geometric primitives corresponding to faces, edges, and vertices of the triangulation.

These iterators are non-mutable, bidirectional and their value types are respectively Periodic_triangle, Periodic_segment and Periodic_point. They are all invalidated by any change in the triangulation. If the periodic triangulation is not computed in the 1-sheeted covering space, these iterators can be used to retain only the geometric primitives in the original domain. This can be controlled using the enum Iterator_type, see CGAL::Periodic_2_triangulation_2::Iterator_type.

center.bold: The four different modes of the geometric iterators: STORED, STORED_COVER_DOMAIN, UNIQUE, UNIQUE_COVER_DOMAIN. Note that in case of computing in the 1-sheeted covering space, stored and unique give the same result.

briefdescription.para: Iterates over the points of the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: Its behavior is defined by the Iterator_type it as described on CGAL::Periodic_2_triangulation_2::Iterator_type.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Note that to match another Periodic_point_iterator both must have the same Iterator_type it.

briefdescription.para: Iterates over the segments of the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: Its behavior is defined by the Iterator_type it as described on CGAL::Periodic_2_triangulation_2::Iterator_type.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Note that to match another Periodic_segment_iterator both must have the same Iterator_type it.

briefdescription.para: Iterates over the triangles of the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: Its behavior is defined by the Iterator_type it as described on CGAL::Periodic_2_triangulation_2::Iterator_type.

briefdescription.para: Past-the-end iterator.

detaileddescription.para: Note that to match another Periodic_triangle_iterator both must have the same Iterator_type it.

description.para: The triangulation also provides circulators that allows to visit respectively all faces or edges incident to a given vertex or all vertices adjacent to a given vertex.

These circulators are non-mutable and bidirectional. The operator++ moves the circulator counterclockwise around the vertex while the operator- moves clockwise. A face circulator is invalidated by any modification of the face pointed to. An edge or a vertex circulator are invalidated by any modification of one of the two faces incident to the edge pointed to.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary face incident to v.
Starts at face f.

simplesect.para: Face f is incident to vertex v.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary edge incident to v.
Starts at the first edge of f incident to v, in counterclockwise order around v.

simplesect.para: Face f is incident to vertex v.

briefdescription.para: Starts at an arbitrary vertex adjacent to v.
Starts at the first vertex of f adjacent to v in counterclockwise order around v.

simplesect.para: Face f is incident to vertex v.

briefdescription.para: returns the vertex of the $ i^{th}$ neighbor of f that is opposite to f.
returns the index of f in its $ i^{th}$ neighbor.

memberdef.argsstring: (const Point &p, Locate_type lt, Face_handle loc, int li)
memberdef.name: insert

description.para: The following member functions offer more specialized versions of the insertion or removal operations to be used when one knows to be in the corresponding case.

Insertion of a point on an edge. Insertion in a face. The following functions are mainly intended to be used in conjunction with the find_conflicts() member functions of Delaunay and constrained Delaunay triangulations to perform insertions.

briefdescription.para: Inserts the first vertex.
Inserts vertex v in face f.

detaileddescription.para:
Face f is modified, two new faces are created. If the triangulation contains periodic copies, a point is inserted in all periodic copies.
The point in vertex v lies inside face f.

briefdescription.para: Removes a vertex of degree three.

detaileddescription.para:
Two of the incident faces are destroyed, the third one is modified.
Vertex v is a vertex with degree three.

briefdescription.para: Removes the unique vertex in the triangulation.
creates a new vertex v and use it to star the hole whose boundary is described by the sequence of edges [edge_begin, edge_end].

detaileddescription.para: Returns a handle to the new vertex.

simplesect.para: The triangulation is a triangulation of 1 sheet

memberdef.argsstring: (Point p, EdgeIt edge_begin, EdgeIt edge_end, FaceIt face_begin, FaceIt face_end)
memberdef.name: star_hole

briefdescription.para: same as above, except that the algorithm first recycles faces in the sequence [face_begin, face_end] and create new ones only when the sequence is exhausted.

simplesect.para: The triangulation is a triangulation of 1 sheet

briefdescription.para: Changes the domain.

detaileddescription.para: Note that this function calls clear(), i.e., it erases the existing triangulation.

briefdescription.para: Returns $ i+1$ modulo 3.
Returns $ i+2$ modulo 3.
Returns the degree of the vertex v

description.para: The responsibility of keeping a valid triangulation belongs to the users if advanced operations are used.
Obviously the advanced user, who implements higher levels operations may have to make a triangulation invalid at some times. The following method is provided to help the debugging.

briefdescription.para: Checks the combinatorial validity of the triangulation and also the validity of its geometric embedding.

detaileddescription.para: This method is mainly a debugging help for the users of advanced features.

briefdescription.para: Return all geometric primitives as they are stored internally in Triangulation_data_structure_2.
Return only one representative of each geometric primitive even if the triangulation is computed in a multiply sheeted covering space.

detaileddescription.para: Choose the representative whose maximum offset is minimal but non-negative in each direction of space.

briefdescription.para: Same as STORED but return additionally all primitives whose intersection with the original domain of the current covering space is non-empty.
Same as UNIQUE but return additionally all primitives whose intersection with the original domain is non-empty.
The enum Iterator_type is defined by Periodic_2_triangulation_2 to specify the behavior of geometric iterators.
when the located point coincides with a vertex of the triangulation
when the point is in the relative interior of an edge
when the point is in the interior of a facet
when the triangulation is empty
The enum @ is defined by Periodic_2_triangulation_2 to specify which case occurs when locating a point in the triangulation.

detaileddescription.para: If the triangulation does not contain any points EMPTY is returned.

briefdescription.para: Writes the triangulation t into the stream os.

simplesect.para: The output operator must be defined for Point.

briefdescription.para: Reads a triangulation from stream is and assigns it to t.

simplesect.para: The input operator must be defined for Point.

briefdescription.para: The class Periodic_2_triangulation_2 represents a 2-dimensional triangulation of a point set in $ \mathbb T_c^2$.

detaileddescription.para:
The class Periodic_2_triangulation_2 has two template parameters. The first one
Traits
is the geometric traits, it is to be instantiated by a model of the concept Periodic_2TriangulationTraits_2.
The second parameter
TDS
is the triangulation data structure, it has to be instantiated by a model of the concept TriangulationDataStructure_2 with some additional functionality in faces. By default, the triangulation data structure is instantiated by CGAL::Triangulation_data_structure_2 < CGAL::Triangulation_vertex_base_2<Gt>, CGAL::Periodic_2_triangulation_face_base_2<Gt> > >.
Traversal of the Triangulation
The periodic triangulation class provides several iterators and circulators that allow one to traverse it.
The I/O operators are defined for iostream. The format for the iostream is an internal format.
The information in the iostream is:

listitem.para: the number of sheets of the covering space as in number_of_sheets()
the non-combinatorial information of vertices (point resp. point-offset pairs, etc.)
the indices of the vertices of each face
the indices of the neighbors of each face, where the index corresponds to the preceding list of faces
the offsets corresponding to the vertices of the faces
the non-combinatorial information of each face

detaileddescription.para: Locate is implemented by a randomized walk from a vertex of the face given as optional parameter (or from an arbitrary vertex of if no optional parameter is given).
Insertion of a point is done by locating a face that contains the point, and then splitting this face. Apart from the location, insertion takes a time $ O(1)$.

Removal of a vertex is more difficult than in the Euclidean space, since the star of a vertex may not be disjoint from the star of a virtual copy of that vertex. Therefore generic removal of vertices is not implemented. Several more constrained cases are implemented: the removal of the last vertex in the triangulation and the removal of a vertex of degree 3.

The face, edge, and vertex iterators on features are derived from their counterparts visiting all (non-virtual and virtual) features which are themselves derived from the corresponding iterators of the triangulation data structure.
